en.value: What is the writer trying to suggest in this autobiographical text?&nbsp;
en.comp:
Directions: Read the autobiographical story given below and answer the questions that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate options.

1. Let me tell you about a young boy who made a model car all on his own. The boy is me. Six years ago when I was just 11 and the car was small and simple but in my imagination it was a high-speed, Formula-1 racing car, speeding along the race track.

2. It was during the summer holidays and workmen were building a new driveway and garage beside our house. While watching the workmen I had an idea. I'd build a car to drive into the garage in celebration of the new addition to our home. I told my mother and drew up complicated plans but I couldn't find the right material. So I gave up and spent a miserable couple of days doing nothing. My mother noticed that I'd stopped working and asked me why. She suggested that maybe I should change my plans to fit the material I had, rather than give up.

3. And that's just what I did. I found pieces of wood in my father's workshop and made my car from anything that was lying around the house. I found a small engine from a toy plane of mine, I added that. The power came from a battery attached with some wire I found in a cupboard.

4. By the time the garage was finished, so was my car. I called my family outside the house, connected the wires, started the engine and placed the car on the driveway. It was fast and I had to run to the garage to rescue it before it crashed into the new door. My family clapped and I smiled proudly. Thanks to my mother, I learnt the value of seeing a project through to its end. Soon I was making plans for my next project: a helicopter !

options.value: That everyone should try making something
Recommend a type of car that is easy to make&nbsp;
Explain how he learned not to give up on an idea&nbsp;
Give information about where to find good model cars

en.value: According to the poet, what is life?&nbsp;
en.comp:
Directions: Read the extract given below and answer the questions that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate options.

Life is but a stopping place, a pause in what's to be,

A resting place along the road, to sweet eternity. _________ 2

We all have different journeys,

Different paths along the way,

We all were meant to learn some things

But never meant to stay. _________ 6

Our destination is a place, far greater than we know,

For some the journey is quicker, for some it's slow. _________ 8

And when the journey finally ends,

We claim a great reward

And find an everlasting peace,

Together with the lord. _________ 12

en.comp:
Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate options.

1. Alfred Nobel was born on October 21, 1833 in Sweden. When he was a young boy, one morning, he got up from the dining table and went to his laboratory workshop in the backyard. The next minute, he came running back towards the house. Behind him sounded the loudest explosion anyone in the neighbourhood had ever heard. Alfred's laboratory disappeared in flames.

2. The people of the town were horrified. They were also very angry. They had warned him against experimenting with explosives. They even transported his laboratory on a barge. Then they towed the barge out into the middle of a lake. Now, they would be safe if there was an explosion again. In 1842, Nobel's family moved to Russia where he obtained his education. He travelled widely as a young man and became fluent in five languages. Interested in literature, he wrote poetry, plays and novels when he was free.

3. In the 1860s, he began experimenting with nitroglycerin in his father's factory. He discovered that when mixed with the fine porous powder called kieselguhr, this mixture could be used by construction and mining companies as a safe explosive. There was a need to dig tunnels in the mountains, to build roads through forests and rocky plains, dig canals for ships to sail through and to build railway tracks over mountains. Something was needed to blast away the trees, dirt and stones. They had used gunpowder before, but it was not strong enough. The discovery of dynamite found a solution to their problems.

4. Nobel, who later became very wealthy because of his creations, endowed a $9 million fund in his will as awards for people whose work benefited humanity.

en.value: Which of the following statements is not true about scouting?&nbsp;
en.comp:
Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate options.

1. Scouting is the movement which means a series of organized activities working towards an objective. Scouting movement thus implies both an objective to be achieved and an organization to ensure this. It is a voluntary, non-political, educational movement for young people, open to all without distinction of origin, race or creed, in accordance with the purpose, principles and methods conceived by the founder Lord Baden Powell in 1907.

2. It believes in character training and preparation for good citizenship designed for the benefit of boys and girls. It implies an attractive outdoor life coupled with activities which promote development of character, encourage formation of healthy habits, impart skills useful in everyday life and prepare an individual for service to society and fellowmen. It is a kind of training which instills a sense of responsibility and trustworthiness, offers to the individual opportunities for developing initiative and leadership and promotes self-control, self-reliance and self-direction.

3. The purpose of the movement is to contribute to the education of young people in achieving their full physical, intellectual, emotional, social and spiritual potential as individuals, as responsible citizens and as members of their local, national and international communities. Wherever they may be, members are actively committed to the three principles or fundamental laws and beliefs which must be observed and which represent a code of conduct. They are - Duty to God, Duty to Others and Duty to Self. Scouting seeks to be relevant to young people in the various socio-cultural environments in which they grow up to continuously adjust to meet the needs of young people in a rapidly changing world.
